Solid solution F-MnxCo3-xO4 ultrathin nanosheets: Highly active and selective catalyst for oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural Chenyu Wang Data curation Investigation Writing – original draft 1 Zihan Zhou Data curation Investigation Visualization 1 Peijun Ji Supervision Methodology Writing – review & editing ⁎ College of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China College of Chemical Engineering Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing China College of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Chenyu Wang and Zihan Zhou contributed equally to this work. Ultrathin nanosheets (F-MnCo) with a thickness of ∼1.7 nm are synthesized by incubation of NaF, Co(CH3COO)2, and KMnO4 in aqueous solution at room temperature. F-MnCo is comprised of the self-assembled CoOOH and Co(OH)F nanocrystals and highly dispersed MnO2. Through the calcination at 230 °C, CoOOH and Co(OH)F are pyrolyzed to form F-Co3O4, with manganese being concomitantly embedded in the lattice of F-Co3O4. The synthesized F-MnxCo3-xO4 is a solid solution, exhibiting a structure of ultrathin nanosheets with a thickness of ∼1.1 nm. F-MnxCo3-xO4 has been applied as catalyst for the oxidations of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) and alcohols, exhibiting an excellent catalytic activity and a high aldehyde selectivity. The ultrathin nanosheets can facilitate mass transfer of reactants and provide more open active sites. High proportion of surface lattice oxygen, abundant oxygen vacancy, excellent oxygen mobility, and uniformly embedded manganese in the lattice also contribute to F-MnxCo3-xO4 exhibiting the excellent catalytic activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Solid solution Fluorine Ultrathin nanosheets Selective oxidation Biomass Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes is an important fundamental transformation in organic chemistry [1,2]. Selection oxidation reaction is also one of the most important steps for the conversion of biomass to functional chemicals [2–4]. 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) is an important biomass platform compound being converted from sugars or cellulose [3–6]. HMF contains one furan ring bearing hydroxymethyl and aldehyde functional groups. Oxidation of HMF can produce a series high-value chemicals like 2,5-furandialdehyde (DFF), 5-formylfuran-2-carboxlic acid (FFCA), 5-(hydroxymethyl) furan-2-carboxylic acid (HMFCA) and 2,5- furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [8–10]. DFF is a valuable precursor in the synthesis of important fine chemicals, fungicides, antifungal agents, furan resins, macrocyclic ligands, and novel polymers, as DFF contains one furan ring and unsaturated dialdehyde groups [2,7,8]. As the unsaturated aldehyde group is reactive to form other intermediates, the production DFF from HMF with high selectivity tend to be a subtle task. As shown in Table S1, the product selectivity of HMF oxidation depend on many factors, including the catalyst, solvent, oxidant, and reaction conditions. The presence of water tended to facilitate the hydration of aldehyde groups of DFF and HMF and subsequent oxidation to acids [11,12]. Therefore, the use of water as the solvent is not a good choice from the point of DFF selectivity. Cobalt oxide and manganese oxide materials have been shown to possess a good activity for the oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes [7,10–16]. Normally, these metal oxide materials based catalytic systems operate by a Mars–Van-Krevelen mechanism involving an exchange between aerial and lattice oxygen [7,10]. Therefore, the mobility and accessibility of lattice oxygen molecules are believed to be crucial factors for the activity of the catalyst. Compared with the single metal oxides, cobalt manganese bimetallic oxides have shown a better catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes, because the synergetic effect between two metals increase the lattice oxygen content and the mobility of the lattice oxygen molecules [10,16–20]. Co2Mn3O8 exhibited a higher activity than the single metal oxides in the oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes [17]. A Mn doped Co3O4 (Mnx-Co3O4) could oxidize 19 alcohols to aldehydes or ketones with a 99.9% selectivity. The yield of 4-methylbenzyl aldehyde from the oxidation of 4-methylbenzyl alcohol by Mnx-Co3O4 is 100%. While the yield 4-methylbenzyl aldehyde under the catalysis of Co3O4 is only 1.4% [18]. MnCo2O4 gave a benzyl alcohol conversion 82.3% and 100% selectivity for benzaldehyde, which are much higher than those by Mn3O4 [19]. Cobalt manganese bimetallic oxides have been explored for their catalytic performance in the oxidation of HMF to DFF. Mn doped cobalt oxide achieved a HMF conversion 80.0%, which is ∼ 4.4 times that obtained by cobalt oxide [10]. Mn-Co bimetallic oxide displayed a HMF conversion 42.6%, which are 2.2 and 13.3 times than those obtained by manganese oxide and cobalt oxide, respectively [20]. Compared to bulk materials, ultrathin metal oxides nanosheets have a higher surface to volume ratio, confined thickness, and abundant open active sites [21,22]. Ultrathin Co-Mn bimetallic oxides nanosheets, having the advantages of bimetallic oxides and two-dimensional (2D) structures, are highly preferred for obtaining superior catalytic performances [23–32]. Mn-Co bimetallic oxides nanosheets were reported to be prepared by exfoliation from the mother layered crystals [23,24]. Co-substituted manganese oxide nanosheets with a thickness of 0.8 nm and a high crystallinity were synthesized by exfoliation from the mother layered crystals, and the preparation process last 2 weeks [23]. By an electrodeposition process, cobalt-manganese oxide nanosheets with a thickness 15 nm were loaded on a 3D graphene [25]. Cobalt-manganese oxide nanosheets were synthesized using graphene oxide, carbon nanotubes, and cordierite honeycombs as the sacrificial template [26–28]. The nanosheets of cobalt-manganese bimetallic oxide with a thickness 7.7 ∼14 nm were obtained through calcination of the precursor precipitates in air at 300 °C for 2 h [29]. 2D Co-Mn oxide nanosheets were prepared by a low-temperature oxidation of bimetallic Co-Mn metal-organic-framework nanosheets [30]. The content of Mn in the Co-Mn oxide nanosheets was in the range of 0.06∼0.28 wt.%. A cobalt manganese oxide with a thickness of less than 50 nm exhibited a better catalytic activity for benzene oxidation [31]. A series of oxide nanosheets with different Co and Mn ratios were prepared by the solvothermal method [32]. The solid solution nanosheets with a thickness 25 ∼ 90 nm displayed excellent high-performance for lithium-ion batteries. Co-based fluorides, like fluorine doped Co(OH)2 and CoOHF, are not oxygen-resistant [33,34]. Under the air condition, Co-based fluorides were gradually oxidized and converted to fluorine doped Co3O4 as the temperature increased above 200 ℃ [33,34]. Fluorine is the element with the highest electronegativity (δ = 4.0). Fluorine doping resulted in the weakening of metal-oxygen bonds, which contributed to the formation of oxygen vacancy and increase of the mobility of surface lattice oxygen [35–38]. These effects prompted the selective adsorption of target species and oxidization activity of the active sites over the fluorine doped cobalt oxides [35–38]. In this work, solid solution F-MnxCo3-xO4 ultrathin nanosheets with a thickness of ∼1.1 nm have been prepared, as illustrated in Scheme 1 . Fluorine-doped manganese-cobalt hydroxide nanosheets (F-MnCo) were synthesized by incubation of NaF, cobalt acetate, and potassium permanganate in aqueous solution at room temperature. F-MnCo is comprised of the self-assembled CoOOH and Co(OH)F nanocrystals with the formed MnO2 highly dispersed in the F-MnCo nanostructure. Through calcination of F-MnCo at 230 °C for 3 h under air, the CoOOH and Co(OH)F nanocrystals are oxidized to fluorine-doped cobalt oxide. Through the combination of the formed fluorine-doped cobalt oxide with the highly dispersed MnO2, fluorine-doped bimetallic oxides solid solution nanosheets, F-MnxCo3-xO4, are produced. Having the advantages of fluorine-doped bimetallic oxides solid solution and two-dimensional (2D) structures, F-MnxCo3-xO4 are highly expected for obtaining superior catalytic performances for the selective oxidation of HMF to DFF. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (Co(C2H3O2)⋅4H2O, AR), sodium fluoride (NaF, AR), 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, ≥98%), and 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF, ≥98%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Shanghai, China). Methanol (AR), acetonitrile (AR) and potassium permanganate (KMnO4, 98%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent (Shanghai, China). The chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of solid solution F-MnxCo3-xO4 nanosheets 80 mL of the cobalt acetate solution in methanol (40 mM) and 80 mL of the potassium permanganate solution in water (40 mM) were added into 360 mL of the sodium fluoride solution (40 mM) in methanol/water (v:v 2:1). The mixture was incubated at 25 °C for 4 h, and then the precipitate was collected by centrifugation. The precipitate was washed thoroughly with deionized water and methanol, and then dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 2 h. The molar ratio of KMnO4 to Co(C2H3O2) was 1:1, and the fluorine-doped manganese-cobalt hydroxide nanosheet was designated as F-MnCo. F-MnCo was heated at 230 °C for 3 h in a tubular calciner under air atmosphere. After annealing, the solid solution (named as F-MnxCo3-xO4) nanosheets were obtained. 2.3 Selective oxidation reaction of HMF and product analysis In a typical procedure, 0.5 mmol of HMF, 5 mL of acetonitrile, and 100 mg catalyst were added into a 25 mL high pressure autoclave reactor. The reactor was purged with O2, then O2 was induced at a pressure of 5 bar. The reactor was heated to the desired temperature with a stirring speed at 200 rpm. After a specific reaction time, the autoclave reactor was transferred to ice water for cooling to room temperature. The catalyst was collected through centrifugation. The concentrations of HMF and DFF in the reaction solution were analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (Shimadzu LC-10A) with a Diamonsil C18 column and an UV–vis detector at 284 nm. The mobile phase at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min−1 consisted of trifluoroacetic acid (0.1%) and acetonitrile (0.85/0.15; V/V). The concentrations of FFCA and FDCA in the reaction solution were analyzed using the high-performance liquid chromatography (Shimadzu LC-10A) with an Aminex HPX-87H ion exclusion column and a refractive index (RI) detector. The mobile phase was 5 mM H2SO4 flowing at a rate of 0.6 mL/min. The column oven was set to 65 °C. Consecutive use of F-MnxCo3-xO4 was performed with 1 h reaction for each cycle. After each run, the catalyst was recovered by being filtrated through a membrane, and washed thoroughly with water and ethanol sequentially. Then the catalyst was dried at 80 ℃ under vacuum for 12 h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Ultrathin nanosheets F-MnCo Fig. 1 a and b shows the SEM and TEM images for F-MnCo, which were synthesized by incubation of NaF, Co(CH3COO)2, and KMnO4 dissolved in water at room temperature. The EDS spectrum confirmed the presence of the elements of Co, Mn, O, and F (Fig. 1c). The AFM image shows that the F-MnCo ultrathin nanosheets have a thickness of ∼1.7 nm (Fig. 1d). The images of scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) show that the elements Co, Mn, O and F are evenly distributed in F-MnCo (Fig. 1e). Fig. 2 a shows the XPS spectra for F-MnCo. The bands at 779.9 eV, 781.3 eV, and 783.0 eV are assigned to Co3+, Co2+, and Co-F, respectively [39–41] . The decomposition spectra of Mn 2p are shown in Fig. 2b. The peaks at 644.2 eV and 642.3 eV are attributed to Mn4+ and Mn3+, respectively [42,43]. Fig. 2c shows the O 1 s spectrum. The bands at 529.9, 531.1, 531.8, and 532.8 eV are assigned to the lattice oxygen (Olattice), oxygen defect (Ovacancy), hydroxyl oxygen (OOH), and oxygen in the absorbed water (OH2O), respectively [44,45]. Fig. 2d shows the F 1 s spectrum. Fig. 2e shows the XRD pattern, exhibiting characteristic diffraction peaks of CoOOH (JCPDS NO. 26–0480) and Co(OH)F (JCPDS NO. 50–0827). Fig. 2f shows the HRTEM image exhibiting six different lattice fringe spaces. 0.219, 0.231, and 0.242 nm are for CoOOH, corresponding to the planes of (0 0 6), (0 1 2), and (1 0 1), respectively [46–48] . 0.252, 0.257, and 0.267 nm are for Co(OH)F, corresponding to the planes of (1 1 1), (4 0 0), and (2 0 1), respectively [49,50]. To investigate the reason of forming the 2D structure of F-MnCo, the materials MnCo and F-Co were prepared and characterized. MnCo is prepared by the incubation of Co(CH3COO)2 and KMnO4 in the aqueous solution at room temperature for 4 h. It is a bulk material as shown in supplementary Fig. S1a. The XRD pattern (Fig. S1b) indicates that MnCo comprises CoOOH and MnO2, which are formed due to the redox reaction between MnO4 − and Co2+. F-Co is prepared by the incubation of NaF and Co(CH3COO)2 in the aqueous solution at room temperature for 4 h. It exhibits a 2D morphology as shown in Fig. S1c. The XRD pattern (Fig. S1d) shows that F-Co exhibits the characteristic peak of Co(OH)F, which is formed by the interactions among F −, Co2+, and OH−. The characterizations of MnCo and F-Co indicate that the driving force for the formation of the F-MnCo ultrathin nanosheets is attributed to the formation of Co(OH)F nanocrystals. The F-MnCo ultrathin nanosheets as shown in Fig. 1 were obtained after 4 h incubation. To investigate the mechanism of forming the F-MnCo ultrathin nanosheets, the samples after 0.5 h, 1 h and 6 h incubations were analyzed by measuring XRD patterns. Supplementary Fig. S2 shows that the samples after 0.5 h and 1 h incubations exhibited the characteristic peaks of CoOOH and Co(OH)F. Crystal diffraction peak corresponding to MnO2 was not found in the XRD pattern of F-MnCo. However, the characteristic peaks of MnO2 appeared in the XRD pattern of the sample after 6 h incubations. Fig. S3 show the HRTEM images for the samples after 0.5 and 1 h incubations. 0.440, 0.242, and 0.231 nm are for CoOOH, corresponding to the planes of (0 0 3), (1 0 1), and (0 1 2), respectively [46–48]. 0.267, 0.252, and 0.216 nm are for Co(OH)F, corresponding to the planes of (2 0 1), (1 1 1), and (4 1 0), respectively [49,50]. The HRTEM images of the sample after 6 h (Fig. S4) contains the lattices of CoOOH and Co(OH)F, and the lattice of MnO2. These results prove that the redox reaction between Co2+ and MnO4 − generated MnO2. Detectable MnO2 nanocrystals were formed if the samples incubated after 6 h. The STEM images (Fig. 1e) have shown that the elements Co, Mn, O and F are evenly distributed in F-MnCo. The contents of Mn and Co in F-MnCo are 0.303 g/g and 0.270 g/g (determined by ICP-AES), respectively. The molar ratio of Mn to Co is 1.2. The absence of XRD peaks of Mn oxide is not due to the lower loading of Mn. Thus, it is speculated that the formed MnO2 is highly dispersed in the F-MnCo nanostructure. 3.2 Solid solution F-MnxCo3-xO4 Fig. 3 a and b shows the SEM and TEM images for the F-MnxCo3-xO4 ultrathin nanosheets, which were formed through the calcination of the F-MnCo ultrathin nanosheets at 230 °C for 3 h under the air atmosphere. The EDS spectrum (Fig. 3c) confirmed the presence of the elements Co, Mn, O, and F. The AFM image shows that the thickness of F-MnxCo3-xO4 is ∼1.1 nm (Fig. 3d). The STEM images show that the elements Co, Mn, O and F are evenly distributed in F-MnxCo3-xO4 (Fig. 3e). The Co 2p spectra (Fig. 4 a) indicates the presence of Co3+ and Co2+ in F-MnxCo3-xO4, and Co2+ coordinating to F (Co-F). In comparison to F-MnCo, F-MnxCo3-xO4 contains more Co3+. The spectra of Mn 2p are shown in Fig. 4b. The decomposition spectra of Mn 2p indicates that there exists Mn3+ (642.3 eV) and Mn2+ (640.9 eV) in F-MnxCo3-xO4 [9,51–53]. In comparison to F-MnCo, there is no peak for Mn4+ in F-MnxCo3-xO4. The XPS spectra indicate that there are more Co3+ and Mn3+ in F-MnxCo3-xO4. It is possibly ascribed to that Mn4+ underwent redox reaction with Co2+ during the calcination process. The XPS spectra of O 1 s are shown in Fig. 4c. There is no hydroxyl group in F-MnxCo3-xO4, and the amount of Ovacancy is relatively increased. Fig. 4d shows the F 1 s spectrum. Fig. 4e shows the XRD pattern. Only the diffraction peaks of Co3O4 (JCPDS NO. 42–1467) were observed. The EDS and XPS spectra have proved that manganese is present in F-MnxCo3-xO4, and the STEM image has shown that manganese is evenly distributed in F-MnxCo3-xO4. However, there are no diffraction peaks corresponding to Mn oxides in the XRD pattern. Hence it can be speculated that, CoOOH and Co(OH)F are pyrolyzed to form F-Co3O4, and manganese is uniformly embedded in the lattice of F-Co3O4. The synthesized F-MnxCo3-xO4 is a solid solution, exhibiting a structure of ultrathin nanosheets with a thickness of ∼1.1 nm. Fig. 4f shows the HRTEM image. The lattice fringe spaces of 0.481, 0.293, 0.249 and 0.213 nm were observed. Because the radius of Mn3+ (0.058 nm) and Mn2+ (0.067 nm) are slightly larger than Co3+ (0.055 nm) and Co2+ (0.065 nm) [17,54], the lattice fringe spaces of F-MnxCo3-xO4 are slightly larger than the lattice fringe spaces of the pure Co3O4. Fig. 5 a shows the EPR spectra of F-MnxCo3-xO4. The peak at g = 2.003 indicates the presence of oxygen vacancy [55]. F-MnxCo3-xO4 contains a high proportion of Mn3+. Mn3+ tend to give one of four 3d electrons to the antibonding eg orbitals, and have an electronic configuration of Mn3+(t2g 3-eg1). The electronic configuration of Mn3+ is different from Co3+ (t2g 6-eg0). The special electronic configuration of Mn3+ induced the elongation of the Mn-O bonds and the lattice distortion. The phenomenon caused by Mn3+species is known as Jahn–Teller effect [18,56,57]. Fluorine doping also resulted in the weakening of metal-oxygen bonds, which contributed to the formation of oxygen vacancy and the increase of the mobility of surface lattice oxygen [35–38]. The high content of oxygen vacancy in F-MnxCo3-xO4 is possibly ascribed to the presence of Mn3+ and fluorine doping. The oxygen vacancy can provide sufficient sites for reactants adsorption and oxygen storage. The oxidation capacity benefits from the high proportion of oxygen vacancy. The oxygen storage capacity and mobility also have important effects on the oxidation activity of catalysts [58]. Both oxygen vacancy and surface lattice oxygen participate in the storage and mobility of oxygen during oxidation reactions. To examine the mobility of oxygen, O2-TPD was performed. Fig. 5b shows the O2-TPD curves for F-MnxCo3-xO4 and Co3O4. For the cobalt or manganese metal oxides, the oxygen desorption peaks in the range of 50 ∼ 300 °C, 300 ∼ 600 °C, and >600 °C are generally assigned to the desorption of adsorbed oxygen on the surface, the removal of surface lattice oxygen, and the removal of the lattice oxygen by the pyrolysis of bulk metal oxides [59–63]. F-MnxCo3-xO4 is a 2D material, exhibiting strong oxygen desorption peaks in the range of 300 ∼ 600 °C. It is implied that F-MnxCo3-xO4 has a larger number of surface lattice oxygen than Co3O4, indicating that the mobility of oxygen of F-MnxCo3-xO4 is superior to that of Co3O4. The high mobility of surface lattice oxygen is attributed to the high proportion of Mn3+, and the lattice oxygen can be easily released due to the Jahn-Teller effect related to the Mn-O bond elongation. For Co3O4, the hydrogen consumption peaks associated with the Co3+ reduction to Co2+ and with the Co2+ reduction to metallic Co are located at ∼345 °C and ∼ 430 °C, respectively [11]. For MnOx, the hydrogen consumption peak related to the reduction of the Mn3+ reduction to Mn2+ is located at ∼460 °C [11]. The hydrogen consumption peaks of Co3O4 and MnOx are usually above 300 °C. Fig. 5c shows the H2-TPR profile of F-MnxCo3-xO4. The hydrogen consumption peak of F-MnxCo3-xO4 is shifted to a lower temperature region (below 300 °C). The lower onset of hydrogen reduction temperature suggests that F-MnxCo3-xO4 has a higher mobility of lattice oxygen. The solid solution F-MnxCo3-xO4 ultrathin nanosheets and the high proportion of Mn3+ contribute to the higher oxygen mobility of F-MnxCo3-xO4. 3.3 Application of F-MnxCo3-xO4 as catalyst for the oxidation of hmf F-MnxCo3-xO4 has been used for the HMF conversion. Different dosages of F-MnxCo3-xO4 were used for the HMF oxidation. Without using any catalyst (0 mg), the reaction could not proceed (supplementary Fig. S5). It has been shown that the HMF conversion is increased linearly with the dosage of F-MnxCo3-xO4, when the reactions were performed under stirring (Supplementary Fig. S5). The conversion of HMF is decreased less than 5%, when the reaction was performed over 100 mg of F-MnxCo3-xO4 in the absence of stirring. F-MnxCo3-xO4 exhibits the structure of ultrathin nanosheets, the open active sites distributed on the ultrathin nanosheets can significantly enhance the mass transfer during the reactions. Fig. S6 shows the HMF conversion and DFF yield with reaction time. After 10 min, the HMF conversion was 66.3%. DFF was the only product as confirmed by the GC–MS analysis (Fig. S7a, S7b). The HPLC spectra clearly show the appearance of two peaks representing HMF and DFF (Fig. S8). After 20 min reaction, the HMF conversion was 84.7%. The HMF conversion 94.9% was achieved after 30 min reaction. After 60 min, the HMF conversion was increased to 97.6%. F-MnxCo3-xO4 has exhibited an excellent reusability as shown in Fig. 6 . The HMF conversion was 95.2% after 5th cycle of reuse. Furthermore, the concentration of metal ions in the reaction mixture were measured. The concentration of Mn ion was less than 8 ppm with no detectable Co ion, indicating the leaching of the metal ions from the catalyst can be negligible. Figs. 7 and S9 show that after 5th cycles of reuse, for the recovered F-MnxCo3-xO4, the morphology and the composition and the oxidation states of Co and Mn had little change in comparison with the that of fresh F-MnxCo3-xO4. These results further prove the good stability of F-MnxCo3-xO4. Reaction conditions: 100 mM HMF in 5 mL acetonitrile, O2 5 bar, 100 mg catalyst, 130 °C. F-MnxCo3-xO4 was compared with the Mn and Co-based catalysts as listed in Table 1 . 50 mg mesoporous Mn doped cobalt oxide (Mn/CoOx) exhibited a HMF conversion 80% with a DFF selectivity of 96.0% after 4 h reaction at 130 °C [10]. 50 mg Mn-Co bimetallic oxide (Mn0.5 Co0.5 O) displayed a HMF conversion 42.6% with a DFF selectivity of 98.0% after 2 h reaction at 140 °C [20]. 200 mg MnCo2O4 achieved a HMF conversion 70.1% with a DFF selectivity 100% after 3 h reaction at 130 °C [11]. 50 mg MnOx/MnCO3/Fe2O3 nanocomposite achieved a HMF conversion 48.0% with a DFF selectivity 100% after 2 h reaction at 100 °C [64]. In contrast, 50 mg F-MnxCo3-xO4 has achieved the HMF conversion 95.7% after 2 h reaction at 130 °C. 100 mg F-MnxCo3-xO4 has achieved the HMF conversion 94.9% after 0.5 h reaction and 97.6% after 1 h reaction at 130 °C, and the DFF selectivity is larger than 99%. Furthermore, the performance of F-MnxCo3-xO4 over higher concentration of HMF were evaluated. When the concentration of HMF is increased to 200 mM and 300 mM, the DFF selectivity is kept larger than 98%, the HMF conversions over 100 mg F-MnxCo3-xO4 are decreased to 81.3% and 67.9%, respectively. By increasing the catalyst dosage to 200 mg, the HMF conversions of 96.2% and 85.8% are achieved for the initial concentrations of HMF of 200 mM and 300 mM, respectively. F-MnxCo3-xO4 also exhibits a high catalytic activity for the oxidation of alcohols, as listed in Table 2 . 3.4 Mechanism of the catalysis by F-MnxCo3-xO4 To investigate the possible catalytic pathway, the reaction under the N2 atmosphere was carried out. Under the N2 atmosphere, 53.3% of HMF was converted with a DFF selectivity 96.8% after 0.5 h reaction (entry 2 in Table 3 ). In contrast, under the O2 atmosphere (entry 1 in Table 3) after 0.5 h reaction, 94.9% of HMF was converted with a DFF selectivity 99.6%. The recovered F-MnxCo3-xO4 (F-MnxCo3-xO4*) after 0.5 h reaction under the N2 atmosphere was subjected to measurement of XPS spectra. Fig. 8 a shows the O 1 s XPS spectra. It is indicated that the ratio of lattice oxygen to oxygen vacancy (Olattice / Ovacancy) is decreased to 0.85, in comparison to that of fresh F-MnxCo3-xO4 (1.32). Fig. 8b shows the Mn 2p XPS spectra. It is indicated that the ratio of Mn3+ to Mn2+ of F-MnxCo3-xO4* (2.18) is much lower than that of fresh F-MnxCo3-xO4 (3.72). Fig. 8c shows the Co 2p XPS spectra. The ratio of Co3+ to Co2+ is slightly reduced to 0.88 for F-MnxCo3-xO4*, compared to that of fresh F-MnxCo3-xO4 (0.93). Under the N2 atmosphere, the oxidation of the HMF consumes the lattice oxygens, and the consumed lattice oxygen cannot be replenished. Entry 3 in Table 3 is the result obtained by shifting the N2 atmosphere after 0.5 h reaction to the O2 atmosphere for additional 0.5 h reaction. The HMF conversion 92.1% with a DFF selectivity 95.1% were obtained. The recovered F-MnxCo3-xO4 (F-MnxCo3-xO4**) after the 1 h reaction was subjected to measurement of XPS spectra. It is indicated F-MnxCo3-xO4** exhibited a higher ratio of Olattice to Ovacancy (1.10) and a higher ratio of Mn3+ to Mn2+ (2.79) than F-MnxCo3-xO4*, which exhibited a ratio of Olattice to Ovacancy of 0.85 and a ratio of Mn3+to Mn2+ of 2.18. It is indicated that some of the consumed lattice oxygen under the N2 atmosphere can be replenished under the O2 atmosphere. The results indicate that Mn3+↔Mn2+ cycle is responsible for the activity, while Co3+↔ Co2+ cycle make little contribution to the activity. The results in Table 3 support that the F-MnxCo3-xO4 catalyst operates following the Mars-Van-Krevelen redox mechanism [18,19,64]. During the HMF oxidation, oxygen vacancy is formed as a result of the consumption of the lattice oxygen, followed by the exchanging between the oxygen vacancy and the aerial oxygen. Based on the reaction pathways and catalyst characterizations, the mechanism of the HMF oxidation to DFF over F-MnxCo3-xO4 is proposed as illustrated in Scheme 2 . The oxidation reaction proceeds via the Mn3+↔Mn2+ redox cycles. Surface lattice oxygen oxidizes HMF to DFF, in the meantime Mn3+ is reduced to Mn2+. Then Mn2+ is oxidized to Mn3+ by O2, forming the surface lattice oxygen species. The excellent oxidation capability of the solid solution F-MnxCo3-xO4 ultrathin nanosheets is ascribed to the excellent accessibility of active surface lattice oxygen. F-MnxCo3-xO4 contains a high proportion of Mn3+. The elongated Mn-O bond caused by Mn3+ decreases the energy barrier of Mn3+↔Mn2+ redox cycles, and thus improving the mobility of lattice oxygen of F-MnxCo3-xO4. The structure of ultrathin nanosheets can make the abundant lattice oxygen to be easily accessible by HMF. F-MnxCo3-xO4* represents the recovered F-MnxCo3-xO4 after 0.5 h reaction under N2 atmosphere; F-MnxCo3-xO4** represents the recovered F-MnxCo3-xO4 after 0.5 h reaction under the N2 atmosphere and additional 0.5 h reaction under the O2 atmosphere. 4 Conclusions The solid solution F-MnxCo3-xO4 ultrathin nanosheets were synthesized in an easy and convenient way. Manganese is uniformly embedded in the lattice of F-Co3O4 of F-MnxCo3-xO4. The ultrathin nanosheets possess a high proportion of surface lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancy with an excellent oxygen mobility. The open active sites can greatly reduce the mass transfer resistance. F-MnxCo3-xO4 has been applied as catalyst for the oxidations of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) and alcohols, exhibiting an excellent catalytic efficiency and a high aldehyde selectivity. For catalyzing the oxidation reaction, the F-MnxCo3-xO4 catalyst operates following the Mars-Van-Krevelen redox mechanism. The Mn3+↔Mn2+ cycle is responsible for the catalytic activity of F-MnxCo3-xO4. F-MnxCo3-xO4 contains a high proportion of Mn3+. The elongated Mn-O bond caused by Mn3+ decreases the energy barrier of Mn3+↔Mn2+ redox cycles, thus improving the mobility of lattice oxygen of F-MnxCo3-xO4. coredata.dc:description: Ultrathin nanosheets (F-MnCo) with a thickness of ∼1.7 nm are synthesized by incubation of NaF, Co(CH3COO)2, and KMnO4 in aqueous solution at room temperature. F-MnCo is comprised of the self-assembled CoOOH and Co(OH)F nanocrystals and highly dispersed MnO2. Through the calcination at 230 °C, CoOOH and Co(OH)F are pyrolyzed to form F-Co3O4, with manganese being concomitantly embedded in the lattice of F-Co3O4. The synthesized F-MnxCo3-xO4 is a solid solution, exhibiting a structure of ultrathin nanosheets with a thickness of ∼1.1 nm. F-MnxCo3-xO4 has been applied as catalyst for the oxidations of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) and alcohols, exhibiting an excellent catalytic activity and a high aldehyde selectivity. The ultrathin nanosheets can facilitate mass transfer of reactants and provide more open active sites. High proportion of surface lattice oxygen, abundant oxygen vacancy, excellent oxygen mobility, and uniformly embedded manganese in the lattice also contribute to F-MnxCo3-xO4 exhibiting the excellent catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Solid solution F-MnxCo3-xO4 ultrathin nanosheets: Highly active and selective catalyst for oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural
